H0.text: Hydrogen is the other element that all biochemical molecules have along with oxygen and carbon.

H1.text: Helium is the other element found in all biochemical molecules alongside oxygen and carbon.

H2.text: Nitrogen is the other element that, along with oxygen and carbon, is present in all biochemical molecules.

H3.text: Calcium is the other element that all biochemical molecules contain, along with oxygen and carbon.

A4.text: Living things incorporate inorganic carbon compounds into organic compounds through a network of processes (the carbon cycle) that convert carbon dioxide and a hydrogen source like water into simple sugars and other organic molecules.

A5.text: the organic compound L-isoleucine molecule presents some features typical of organic compounds: carbon–carbon bonds, carbon–hydrogen bonds, as well as covalent bonds from carbon to oxygen and to nitrogen.

A6.text: The bulk of all life forms on Earth consist of just six elements, described by the acronym CHNOPS: carbon, hydrogen, nitrogen, oxygen, phosphorus, and sulfur.
